findings.title: Reentrancy in Collect allows draining funds
findings.explanation: The function uses msg.sender.call.value(_am)() to send ether before updating the user's balance. This allows a malicious contract to reenter Collect and withdraw multiple times before the balance is decreased.
findings.fix_suggestion: Follow the Checks-Effects-Interactions pattern: deduct the amount from the balance before making external calls, or use transfer/send instead of call to limit gas and prevent reentrancy.

findings.title: Unchecked integer overflow/underflow on balance
findings.explanation: The contract updates acc.balance with acc.balance += msg.value and acc.balance -= _am without any overflow or underflow checks, which can lead to incorrect balances if arithmetic wraps around.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use a SafeMath library for all arithmetic operations to ensure that additions and subtractions revert on overflow or underflow.

findings.title: Timestamp dependence for unlockTime
findings.explanation: The contract relies on now (block.timestamp) for calculating unlockTime and for withdrawal eligibility, allowing miners to manipulate the timestamp slightly to their advantage.
findings.fix_suggestion: Avoid critical logic based on block timestamps or add buffers and use block numbers for more predictable timing.

findings.title: DoS risk when external call fails
findings.explanation: If msg.sender.call.value(_am)() fails (e.g., user’s fallback uses more than 2,300 gas or reverts), the contract does not revert and does not reduce the balance, effectively locking the funds permanently.
findings.fix_suggestion: Use require(msg.sender.send(_am)) or require(msg.sender.transfer(_am)) so that failures revert the transaction, or separate the withdraw logic to ensure consistent state.

unmatched_predictions.title: DoS risk when external call fails
